text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new janelle
monae album
the electric lady janelle monae is an r
b and art pop singer songwriter who
turned heads in a big way back in 2010
with her album the arc android easily
one of the most ambitious and conceptual
records in r b music to come out in a
very long time and the thing about this
album is that it's a sequel the second
and third suite in an ongoing series
that janelle monae is kind of penning as
she puts out more albums and this
narrative that janelle monae is penning
it has afrocentric themes futuristic
themes science fiction themes and even
though janelle monae comes through
really heavy with concept i think she
delivers music as well that is just as
grand as her conceptual ambitions the
arc android proved janelle monae was an
incredibly versatile artist delivering
tracks that were influenced by jazz
baroque pop funk soul hip hop now even
though the third suite on this album was
a little disjointed it's still an
incredibly impressive lp and while the
story line the the narrative that
janelle monae pulls together on her
records isn't necessarily like a b c d
1.2 another 0.2 what she does instead is
just creates this entirely different
world in her mind gives you glimpses of
it through her music and through her
lyrics and then plays inside of this
playground she's created to expel some
great songs about love free expression
oppression people living in harmony
gender equality racial struggle and i
would say these themes come through in a
really strong way on this new lp as well
in fact the electric lady adds two more
sweets to the ongoing metropolis series
and puts another empty circle at the end
of all of it implying that there is more
to come and honestly i have no problem
whatsoever with implying that as long as
janelle monae's music stays this funky
stays this thematic stays this
interesting lyrically and stays really
well arranged instrumentally the most
apparent thing to me on this record what
really hit me as i was tripping through
and and this could be a good or a bad
thing are janelle monae's influences for
one prince who she also counts as a
collaborator on this lp also the jackson
5 marvin gaye stevie wonder destiny's
child solange is actually on this lp as
well as erica badu who's on this album
as well we will get more to the
influences later but another thing that
hit me about this record is just how
accessible it is at some points even
though janelle monae seems to be like in
her own little galaxy there's no denying
the huge amount of popularity growth
that has occurred from her first album
to the arc android to this new lp and i
feel like her wanting to bend to those
whims a little bit is displayed big time
in this lp's two primary singles dance
apocalyptic and queen but still even
when trying to appeal in a really big
way i feel like janelle monae puts
effort into her lyrics giving them a
little extra subversiveness that you
could read into the song queen has this
raunchy raunchy groove and funkadelic
style keyboards playing throughout the
track and lyrically it's it's really a
song about being kind of the boldest
person you can be and not worrying about
who that offends or worries or makes
uncomfortable the groove is okay it's a
little corny but the end of the track is
is actually fantastic really gets lifted
up with these wonderful string sections
and janel monet busts this rap verse
with a flow that she returns to at a few
other points on this album when she
feels like she needs to say something
poignant but the verse that she ends
this track off with one of the most
politically charged moments i've ever
heard in a piece of her music it's a
really inspirational gripping and kind
of beautiful declaration of self and the
even catchier dance apocalyptic to me
has a bit of a retro vibe coming from
the instrumentation like an old school
rhythm and blues pop kind of thing going
and lyrically it seems to kind of delve
into being driven crazy and being boxed
in by just the limitations of the modern
world the food tastes like crap you have
allergies from the animals that you have
as house pets you're bathing and bathing
and bathing but nothing really gets the
funk off it's really the most bubble gum
i've ever heard janomone get especially
with kind of the juicy j reference right
at the beginning of the track but to me
instrumentally and melodically too this
song has a bit of a corny quality to it
just like queen does in comparison with
previous singles like cold war or
especially tightrope these two lead
singles definitely don't have the same
amount of
class or wonder or charisma but to me
those two tracks are just the poppier
highlights off this album as far as the
other tracks go on here janelle monae
again kind of gets back to the grand
smooth funky and pristine tracks that
made the arc android so good the song
electric lady the title track off of the
selfie has a hard groove bright bright
synth in the background and just has
this smooth
funky feel to the instrumentation that i
love solange knowles sounds great on the
track and there's just something about
the instrumentation especially some of
the background vocals too after the
chorus
that really reminds me of like some late
90s early 2000s mainstream r b type
stuff and the thing is the r b
influences don't stop here on this album
of course it's never been any secret
that janelle monae is influenced by r b
music she makes r b music
but it's almost as if nearly every track
here kind of tributes a different flavor
or a different era of r b the song prime
time with miguel one of my favorite
tracks on here a beautiful ballad
really to me kind of feels like it's
it's a tip of the hat to the slow jam
the song it's code which
is an all right track it's a track that
to me feels a little generic in style
and melody and and maybe that's because
it feels like a carbon copy of a jackson
5 track there's the song ghetto woman
which is this really jumpy hyper upbeat
ballad with a really strong lyrical
message and it feels kind of like
something stevie wonder would have made
back in the day it's not a bad track i
feel like janelle monae tries to
progress this sound forward by throwing
a lot of effects on her vocals on some
of the instrumentation too but it just
ends up feeling kind of muddy and
unrewarding and there are a few other
tracks on here which feel like these
smooth soul ballads with a really
reflective
personal theme going on in the lyrics
tracks like victory really good tune on
here as well as dorothy dandridge eyes
and the song what an experience feels
like just this pure
soulful 80s r b with some electronic
drums and some really strong glistening
synthesizers and as the song moves along
it's got a little bit of a pop reggae
thing going on on the back end with some
upstroke guitars and as cheesy as some
of that stuff was it's actually a really
good song beautiful tune nice mix on the
instrumentation it has a nice pristine
sound to it and just the refrain to this
track to finish the album off feels so
fitting really what an experience the
electric lady was overall i have a lot
of positive things to say about this
record the production the songs the
instrumentation janomone singing of
course which is always fantastic the
interludes where you kind of have this
really eccentric radio dj talking about
this robot culture that this music is
set in are not only sort of eye-opening
but hilarious but where the shortcomings
come through on this record is in
janelle monae's influences more than on
the arc android and on her debut ep
she kind of does this dance of death
with a lot of them trying to get as
close as possible to them without
completely drowning out her own style
her own essence sometimes that works
like on victory and in other moments
like i said with its code it kind of
just sounds like a regular old jackson 5
track and then on top of that there are
moments of fast-paced pop souls such as
rock and roll and the song look into my
eyes which is a sweet little piece of
baroque pop that both sound like songs
that
could have been on janelle monae's last
album however even though i can draw a
lot of comparisons between the arc
android and the electric lady it's a
different album at least different
enough for me with its interludes and
guest appearances its songs its
production aesthetic its slightly more
political lyrics and the fact that all
together these songs kind of feel like
an all-around tribute to
the world of r b music from its
inception up to the current day i'm
feeling a strong seven to a light eight
on this thing tran
but if you've given this lp a listen
what did you think of it did you love it
hate it why what do you think i should
review next and
that's it
janelle monae the arc android
anthony fantana
forever
